Activity.Name: Training [Skill-Based] : Word Chapter 1 Project 1B Skill-Based Training

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: The case of Phineas Gage is an often-cited example of:
One drawback to the survey method is:
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: it involves only a small sample size.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: the way in which a question is worded can affect the answer.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: If it is shown that students’ grades go down the more hours they spend watching TV, then grades and hours spent watching TV have a __________ correlation.
Which of the following is the strongest correlation?
If researchers find a relationship between students’ grades and the number of hours they spend watching TV:
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: it does not prove that there is a correlation.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: it still does not prove causation.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: The best method to use to determine the cause of a behavior is the:
A(n) ________ specifically names the steps that the experimenter must use to control or measure the variables in the experiment.
The variable that is manipulated in an experiment is the:
In a double-blind experiment, _________ are kept unaware of which participants are in the control group(s) and which participants are in the experimental group(s).
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: both the researcher(s) and the participants

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: In a negative correlation:
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: the variables increase in the same direction.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: the two variables have an inverse relationship.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: The four goals of psychology are accomplished through:
What is the main advantage of laboratory observation?
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: the degree of control it gives the researcher

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: All of the following statements about surveys are true EXCEPT:
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: the order of the questions in the survey can affect its outcome.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: answers to survey questions are resistant to courtesy bias.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: In an experiment, it is best to divide participants into the control or experimental group by:
If there is _________ in a medical experiment, the control group will show changes in the dependent variable even if they are given a harmless substitute rather than a real drug.

If a researcher is observing a third grade classroom in full view of the students and finds that all the students are extremely quiet, polite, and attentive, what would the researcher most likely conclude?
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: The students’ behavior is due to the observer effect.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: If a researcher finds that people’s shoe sizes increase as their height increases, then shoe size and height have a(n):
A drug company conducts a study in which the experimenter gives half of the participants the drug being tested and the other half a placebo. This is an example of:
In testing whether viewing violence on television causes children to behave in increasingly violent ways, the best method would be:
Which research method will allow researchers to determine the cause of a behavior?
________ are defined in the textbook as standards upon which a judgment or decision may be based.
_____ is the rule of thumb stating that if there are two explanations for a phenomenon, the simplest explanation is more often the best one.
In psychology in the twenty-first century:
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: we have learned all there is to know about human behavior and mental processes.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: there are seven major perspectives that are used to explain human behavior and mental processes.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: The theory of operant conditioning was developed by:
________ suggests that behavioral responses are reinforced when rewarded with pleasurable consequences.
When Rashid graduated from college, he believed he had finally achieved his full potential. Abraham Maslow called this type of achievement:
________ is the study of the physical changes in the brain and nervous system during thinking.
The sociocultural perspective studies:
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: how evolution has influenced adaptive human behaviors.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: the effect people have on one another, both individually and in a large group.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Biopsychology has found mounting evidence of a biological cause for:
The bystander effect says that people in a crowd are _____ help someone in trouble as compared to a person witnessing someone in need of help in the absence of others.
Which perspective focuses on the biological bases for universal mental characteristics that all humans share?
Today, Gestalt ideas are part of which branch of psychology?
The idea that sexual orientation may be related to the birth order of male children was posited by researchers in the field of:
According to the behavioral perspective, a child who cries and is rewarded by getting his mother’s attention will:
How does humanism differ from psychodynamic theory and behaviorism?
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: Humanism is a much more "mechanical" theory.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: Humanism focuses on people's ability to direct their own lives.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: ________ are personal judgments based on beliefs rather than facts.
Talking, facial expressions, and movements are elements of:
Within the field of psychology, mental processes refer to:
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: all internal, covert activity of our minds.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Description involves ________ a person's behavior and noting everything about it.

Consider the following statement: "Women avoid computer science because it is stereotypically dominated by males. This, in turn, leads many women to feel that the field is not accessible to them." This is an example of a(n) _______.
A doctor informs the parents of a 14-year-old that, without hospitalization, her anorexia nervosa will worsen and cause grave medical conditions. The doctor is making a(n):
A professional who holds a doctoral degree (but has not attended medical school) and may work in a wide number of vocational settings would be a(n) ________.
The largest subfield of psychology is:
Psychologists in the counseling specialization:
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: must be licensed to practice in their states.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Which of the following psychological professionals must always have a medical degree?
A(n) __________ reviews a proposed study and judges it according to safety and consideration for its participants.
Which of the following is true of doing research with people?
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: The research is the highest priority.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: Sometimes people react in unexpected ways to the manipulations in an experiment.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Animals are used in about ___ percent of all psychological studies.
An institutional review board reviews:
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: a study’s safety and consideration for the research participants.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: If deception is necessary, participants must then be _________ after the study.
Which of the following is a reason researchers prefer to use animals in experiments instead of humans?
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: Researchers need not use anesthesia for surgery.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: Studying long-term effects is much easier.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: The textbook defines a _________ as someone who seeks wisdom and knowledge through thinking and discussion.
The process of objectively examining and measuring one's own thoughts and mental activities is known as:
________ is known as the "father of psychology."
The belief that every experience can be broken down into its individual emotions and sensations is known as:
The first university in the United States to offer classes in psychology was ________ in the late 1870s.
William James was responsible for developing the theory of:

________ was denied a Ph.D. because she was a woman. She went on to achieve many professional accomplishments, including becoming the first female president of the American Psychological Association in 1905.
Hispanic psychologist Jorge Sanchez is known for his research on:
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: intelligence tests and their cultural biases.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Which of the following is TRUE about Gestalt psychology?
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: It was influenced by Darwin's ideas about natural selection.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: It focused on perception of patterns and whole figures and events.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Freud proposed that there is a(n) ________ mind into which we repress all of our threatening urges and desires.
Pavlov's work with learning in dogs focused on the concept of:
Watson’s work with “Little Albert” supported the idea that:
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: children are scared of loud noises.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: phobias can be learned through the process of conditioning.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Mary Cover Jones achieved counterconditioning with “Little Peter” by using:
Wundt referred to the process of examining and measuring one's own thoughts and mental activities as:
Which early perspective in psychology, associated with William James, focused on how the mind allows people to adapt, live, work, and play?
Who was the first female president of the American Psychological Association?
By making a loud noise when "Little Albert" was presented with a rat, John Watson taught the baby to fear rats. This proved that:
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: rats can easily frighten young children.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: phobias could be learned through conditioning.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Which of the following examples is an accurate representation of mental processes as applied to the definition of psychology?
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: Tyler reads a book with his little sister.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: Kaleb feels depressed after receiving a poor grade on his homework.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Dr. Mason observes that the students in her class who read both the text and visual aid presentations tend to perform better on her exams than the students who simply read the text or visual aids alone. Dr. Mason’s observation best depicts which goal of psychology?

Chen is interested in studying the effects of physical exercise on levels of concentration. He hypothesizes that aerobic exercise will improve an individual’s ability to concentrate on various tasks. Chen is most interested in which goal of psychology?

Dr. Garfield believes that while poverty can be detrimental to society, it does provide employment for many in fields such as social work, medicine, psychology, politics, and non-profit organizations. Dr. Garfield’s belief relates best to which early field of psychology?

Doreena is seeing a psychologist because of her intense fear of closed-in spaces. Doreena’s therapist believes that her fear is the result of unresolved conflicts regarding her parents, as well as childhood experiences she had with them. To which school of psychology does Doreena’s therapist most likely belong?

Geo informed his current therapist, Dr. Harvey, that since his visit to the Grand Canyon, he has experienced such an intense fear of heights that he can no longer drive to his job, which requires him to cross a bridge. After realizing that Geo almost suffered a fall while at the Grand Canyon, Dr. Harvey concluded that Geo’s fear of heights must be associated with his near-fall experience. Dr. Harvey’s conclusion best relates to which early approach to psychology?

Ms. Glass tells her students everyday how much she wants everyone to succeed, but that they each must choose to attend class and study effectively in order to be successful. She reminds them that the individual choices they make will dramatically affect their outcomes for success. To which perspective of psychology does Ms. Glass’s philosophy on academic performance best relate?

Since birth, Jared has experienced a disturbing twitch that interferes with his ability to function. Through careful observation, it was discovered that Jared’s uncontrollable behavior may be the result of a genetic predisposition. The psychological perspective that correlates best with this finding is _______.

Pia believes that she is an undercover CIA agent working for the President of the United States. Her delusions disappear, however, whenever she takes her psychotropic medication. Pia is most likely being treated by which of the following?

Dr. Eckler is looking for new ideas to examine and is interested in testing the notion that students who prepare for their exams by cramming will perform more poorly than students who study regularly throughout the semester. The notion being tested best depicts which of the following research concepts?

After investigating the effects of caffeine on learning, Dr. Drake found that the more caffeine an individual consumed, the less information he/she was able to retain. According to the scientific method, which of the following steps should Dr. Drake perform next?

In an effort to learn more about religious cults, Asma attends the meeting of a religious group well known for their cult-like practices and pretends to be interested in joining the group. Which of the following techniques best describes Asma’s approach to gathering research information?

Alejandro wanted to examine people’s reactions to various situations in public places. As part of his study, he set up fake incidents where actors played different scenarios. With cameras rolling and the spotlight shining brightly on the actors, Alejandro’s attempt to capture specific reactions by random bystanders was unsuccessful. Which of the following might best explain Alejandro’s failed research attempt?

Dr. Saltman presents the question, “At what age does the average American college student experience his/her first sexual encounter?” Dr. Saltman’s question might be best addressed through the use of which of the following research methods?
A case study would be the most effective method of research to investigate which of these topics?
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: self-esteem differences in males and females
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: dissociative identity disorder in adolescent transsexuals

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Dr. Arnett found that an increase in the consumption of fast food was linked to an increased risk of heart disease. In this example, which type of correlation is demonstrated?
Which of the following statements indicates a negative correlation?
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: As poverty increases, crime rates increase.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: As healthy eating increases, high blood pressure decreases.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: A researcher is studying the effects of alcohol consumption on driving ability. In this experiment, alcohol consumption is the _________.

Professor Robinson is interested in examining how study breaks influence memory. She allows one group of psychology students to take a single 15-minute break while another group of psychology students takes three 5-minute breaks. What is the dependent variable in this example?
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: the students’ memory of the material

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Which of the following examples best illustrates the placebo effect?
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: You vomit after eating bad meat.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: You drink a non-alcoholic beverage that tastes like beer and begin to feel intoxicate.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: The first step in the scientific method is:
A(n) ________ is a tentative explanation of a phenomenon based on observation.
Testing the hypothesis is all about the goal of ________ a behavior.
Scientists report their results even if an experiment failed because:
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: researchers studying the same things will gain from what has already been learned.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: In psychology, researchers try to find the answers to:
Studying children’s interactions by watching them play on the school playground is an example of:
________ refers to the tendency of observers to see what they expect to see.
Which of the following is a guideline for doing research with people?
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: Participants must be allowed to make an informed decision about participation.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Because psychologists want to be precise and measure as carefully as they can, they use ________ to study psychology.
Mary is a psychologist who focuses on the role of the conscious and unconscious minds. To which perspective does Mary ascribe?
________ focuses on how people think, remember, store, and use information.
Freud’s theory of psychoanalysis:
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: has no place in modern scientific study.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: is still in use by professionals today, with less emphasis on sex and sexual motivations.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Dr. Jonas wanted to determine what would happen if rats were given food every time they completed a maze. He believed they would learn to complete the maze faster. This belief is called

Mrs. O'Connor participated in a study in which she was told she would try out a new allergy medicine. She was in the group that received a sugar pill, but she believed that the pill did indeed help control her allergy symptoms. This phenomenon is known as:
A researcher wants to describe children's normal behavior on the playground. The best method for this research is to use
Which of the following illustrates psychology's goal of control?
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: observing the behavior of children in preschool.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: using rewards to help a smoker give up cigarettes.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: When Mary took the survey in the mall, she noticed that the interviewer was wearing an Obama button. She answered the questions more favorably toward Obama than she might otherwise have, probably because:
Dr. Edwards wants to show a causal relationship between tobacco smoking and cancer. Dr. Edwards should:
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: conduct an experiment using animal participants.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Anna is 45 years old and is suffering from hot flashes and extreme moodiness. From a(n) _____ perspective, Anna's symptoms can be attributed to menopause.
Mrs. Lewis participated in a study in which she was given no treatment for her condition. Mrs. Lewis was in the ________ group.

Sasha sat in the preschool classroom and watched the children play, writing down how well they interacted with each other. The children could see that Sasha was watching them, so they made an attempt to be extra well-behaved for her. Sasha's research will be impacted by:

A drug company is determining the effects of a treatment for depression. Neither the researcher nor the participants know who is getting the treatment and who is given a sugar pill. This type of study is:
Researchers use ________ for reducing bias and error in the measurement of data.
Experimenters control the effects of extraneous or confounding variables upon members of experimental and control groups by using:
Correlation will tell researchers all of the following EXCEPT ________ between variables.
Researchers who allow their expectations about what they will see to affect the results of their observation studies are suffering from:
If a correlation coefficient is positive:
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: only one of the variables goes up.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: the two variables increase in the same direction.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: A ________ has a medical degree and is a medical doctor who specializes in the diagnosis and treatment of psychological disorders.
John Watson believed that phobias:
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: are learned through the process of conditioning.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: What did Watson believe about behavior?
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: that it is related to repressed conflict

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: Freud believed that personality was formed:
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: in the first 6 years of life.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: The psychological perspective that is associated with William James is:
In a negative correlation:
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: a strong correlation is close to +1.00.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: the two variables have an inverse relationship.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: The four goals of psychology are accomplished through:
What is the main advantage of laboratory observation?
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: the degree of control it gives the researcher

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: All of the following statements about surveys are true EXCEPT:
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: the order of the questions in the survey can affect its outcome.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: answers to survey questions are resistant to courtesy bias.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: In an experiment, it is best to divide participants into the control or experimental group by:
If there is _________ in a medical experiment, the control group will show changes in the dependent variable even if they are given a harmless substitute rather than a real drug.
_____ is the rule of thumb stating that if there are two explanations for a phenomenon, the simplest explanation is more often the best one.
According to the behavioral perspective, a child who cries and is rewarded by getting his mother’s attention will:

If a researcher is observing a third grade classroom in full view of the students and finds that all the students are extremely quiet, polite, and attentive, what would the researcher most likely conclude?
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: The students’ behavior is due to the observer effect.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: If a researcher finds that people’s shoe sizes increase as their height increases, then shoe size and height have a(n):
A drug company conducts a study in which the experimenter gives half of the participants the drug being tested and the other half a placebo. This is an example of:
How does humanism differ from psychodynamic theory and behaviorism?
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: Humanism is less like philosophy and more practical.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: Humanism focuses on people's ability to direct their own lives.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: In testing whether viewing violence on television causes children to behave in increasingly violent ways, the best method would be:
Which research method will allow researchers to determine the cause of a behavior?
Which of the following psychological professionals must always have a medical degree?
A doctor informs the parents of a 14-year-old that, without hospitalization, her anorexia nervosa will worsen and cause grave medical conditions. The doctor is making a(n):
Wundt referred to the process of examining and measuring one's own thoughts and mental activities as:
Which early perspective in psychology, associated with William James, focused on how the mind allows people to adapt, live, work, and play?
Who was the first female president of the American Psychological Association?
Today, Gestalt ideas are part of which branch of psychology?
By making a loud noise when "Little Albert" was presented with a rat, John Watson taught the baby to fear rats. This proved that:
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: children are inherently afraid of rats.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: phobias could be learned through conditioning.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: An institutional review board reviews:
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: a study’s safety and consideration for the research participants.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: If deception is necessary, participants must then be _________ after the study.
Which of the following is a reason researchers prefer to use animals in experiments instead of humans?
ActivityQuestionsList.InCorrectOption: There are no limits to what researchers can do with animals.
ActivityQuestionsList.CorrectOption: Studying long-term effects is much easier.

ActivityQuestionsList.Name: The idea that sexual orientation may be related to the birth order of male children was posited by researchers in the field of:
